title: SB 1123
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 51225.3 of the Education Code outlines the course requirements for high school graduation, including three courses in English, two courses in mathematics, and two courses in science. High school graduation requirements include courses in science, social studies, visual or performing arts, foreign language, American government, civics, and economics. American Sign Language can fulfill the foreign language requirement. The subparagraph defines a course in career technical education as one aligned with state standards, including courses offered by regional occupational centers or programs. It clarifies that schools not currently offering such courses are not required to start new programs. Before offering career technical education courses to fulfill graduation requirements, the school district or county office of education must notify parents, teachers, pupils, and the public at a governing board meeting. The impact of offering career technical education courses on availability of courses for admission to California State University and University of California, and the distinction between high school graduation requirements and university admission eligibility. Two courses in physical education required unless exempted. Compliance with specified code provisions is necessary if career technical education courses are used to meet requirements. The governing board of the school district, in collaboration with parents, administrators, teachers, and students, must establish alternative methods for students to fulfill the prescribed course of study. This may include practical demonstrations, work experience, career technical education classes, regional occupational programs, interdisciplinary study, independent study, and credits from postsecondary institutions. Graduation requirements and alternative completion options must be accessible to students, parents, and the public. The department must report to the Legislature on the addition of career technical education courses to meet graduation requirements, comparing enrollment from 2005-2012 to 2013-2017. Reasons for students choosing career technical education courses must be included in the report. The report must include the comparison of career technical education courses offered from 2005-2012 to 2013-2017, the number of courses meeting UC/CSU admission requirements, alignment with California CTE Standards, and courses satisfying visual/performing arts and foreign language requirements. Annual pupil dropout and graduation rates for the 2011–12 to 2014–15 school years will be reported. The Superintendent can use state resources, federal funds, grants, donations, and support from various organizations for this purpose. This section will become inoperative by a specified date. On July 1, after the first fiscal year post the enactment of the act, new career technical education courses aligning with world languages for admission to California State University and University of California must double the current courses meeting admission requirements. This section will be repealed on the following January 1 unless extended or deleted by a later statute. The focus is on real-world application and technical skills. The focus is on aligning world languages with career preparation, emphasizing real-world application and technical content in related career and technical education courses. The provision will be repealed on January 1, 2023, unless a later statute extends the dates.
